reviewText: You might be asking yourself what's so fantastic about yet another pixelated horror game? What's the angle here? What's the big deal and why do you need to suffer through yet another one? Well, sometimes, those pixels can be just as scary as something realistic". Sometimes
date: they just hit just as hard as something as say
recommended:
Amnesia. Maybe even harder.

So what does Into The Gloom do?

I can tell you what it did for me. As a gamer who has a handicap? Who suffers from a chronic illness? This hits me a little harder emotionally than it might for other gamers. This is
voteText: a truly scary game. While we do have the jump scares (and they do offer you a polite warning before you start the game
votesHelpful: we have a more poignant type of horror being told in this game as well. And it's that squishy type of horror that makes you think and dread the future. It makes you question your life. It makes you question yourself.\n\nYou don't expect a game that hardly clocks in an hour of game play per session to do that to you
votesTotal: but hey! There it is!\n\nIt's not long
votesFunny: but it'll give you the creeps. As you keep playing
commentsCount: more endings and possibilities open up to you. More ways to frighten yourself. More ways to keep thinking...\n\nAnd it's cheap. It's certainly worth that price. You can waste about $2.99 on a quick scares and some self reflection
column16: right?\n\nHandicapped gamers: Beware of jump scares that may trigger neurological issues. They will not flash too brightly
column17: but they are there. Your hands may get tired from the controls. Take breaks. (I'm on one now before I try again). Otherwise this is a pretty accessible game for majority of gamers.\n\nAlready an adored addition to my collection."

reviewText:
Note: This game was provided to me for free for review purposes.Overview:Into The Gloom is an exploration horror game where you try to find your place out of a hospital, while finding out who and why you are there. It has all the elements of a good horror game. Spot on sound design, puzzles, documents, and it manages to keep you tense!

The Pros:Art Style - The game's pixelated graphics may seem like a stupid choice in a horror game, but I was surprised how well it worked. For some reason, the corpses look even creepier, and the voxelized environments make you concentrate more on what's important: gameplay and suspense. The red black and white color scheme is also excelent and works well with the theme. The black fog that gives the game it's name is also great, as you can't see too far and it really makes exploring a little more intense.

Multiple Endings - You can end this game with five different endings. This gives it some degree of replayability, and even a challenge, as some of them are harder to achieve.

Scary! - As I've stated before, the game has a very nice scary touch to it. There are some jump scares, but not too many or badly executed. Sometimes, you will see the entities, and have to run for your life, you will hear very errie chants when approaching danger, I love it.The Cons:Short - Despite having multiple endings, the gameplay is rather short, and it is devided in chapters. After your first complete playthrough, you will already know what to do, and there is not story branching in the first chapters, so you will just race through to the exit. Overall you can expect, for your first playthrough, about 3 hours of gameplay, and more if you plan on figuring out all the endings.

Mostly Linear - Many of the areas of the map contain story critical items that are put there in order of necessity. You will almost always find an item just before you need it, to make things easier. Also, there are lots of doors that are locked, so you can never wander in the wrong direction. I would have preffered a huge explorable area, even if devioid of useful content, just to make it seem like you get lost, and make you uneasy when exploring.Conclusion:This is an excellent horror game for cheap, with a decent story and unique art style, which really show you just how scary pixels can get when used correctly. Over par suspense and gameplay, along with multiple endings and great price tag make this game easy to decide on!

If you liked this review or want to see more of my recommended games, you can view my reviews here, and be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

reviewText: This game is phenomenal. First of all, the atmosphere in this game is phenomenal. The eerie sounds always have me on edge, and even the slightest noise or sudden change becomes terrifying. The puzzles are also well done. None of them are too difficult as long as you don't rush through the game and take your time to find all the clues, but still give you a sense of accomplishment as you complete them. Furthermore, there is a huge amount of gameplay with multiple endings for only $3. This game is very much worth your time. I also found ALL of the endings, so if you need help findng those, watch my video!\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sDk0EhJPx8Q&index=1&list=PLKMxTuqznyPMFWfaQvtI_YLWAounc3mNO

Into the Gloom is amazing with multiple endings and more depth than the simple graphics make you think it has. Don't give up on this game after just 15-20 minutes.. you won't see the first bad guy until probably 40 minutes into the game (at least). Trust me, the slow build is so incredibly worth it!

+ smooth controls
+ reasonable puzzles
+ excellent atmosphere
+ crisp graphics (pixelated)
+ eerie sound
+ down right terrifying chase sequences

- slow build (I can see a lot of people giving up on this game before they even meet the main bad guy, don't!! it's worth it!)
- repetitive layout at times
- can get caught on railings etc (super bad during chase sequences)
- some bad-guy appearances can feel unfair (How am i suppose to know he's on the other side of that door!! I'm not psychic!!)

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by its deceptively simple three colour graphics, Into the Gloom proves to be a quality horror experience with an extremely unsettling atmosphere

PROS:

-well made audio, the sound effects are creepy and keep you on edge, the eerie soundtrack is also very nice

-unsettling story that slowly unfolds during gameplay

-graphics,audio and story make up a very creepy atmosphere, the sense of dread can become palpable as you play

-decent puzzles

-not overly reliant on jump scares

-endings/notes unlock through actions done in the game and serve to flesh out the story, giving you a reason to find hidden thing and/or replay the game

CONS:

-a couple clues/puzzles can leave you stuck, this can not only become annoying but also kill the pace

-level layouts can repeat a few times, especially at the beginning

-game saves only when entering a new area,if you have to quit while in the middle of a level you'll have to do everything again. Levels are pretty short though

-some chase sequences can get a bit frustrating

-somewhat short (1 to 3 hours depending on choices and your skill in solving puzzles)

-a couple typos

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=448185590

I got the game for less than 2$ and I was very impressed with it overall; Into The Gloom really nails down what an horror game is all about, playing it was a tense affair that kept me on edge and the story was very interesting.
I fully recommend the game, considering it's well crafted and its cheap price this is a much better proposition than other, more famous and/or costly horror games. Actually quite a few said games could learn a thing of two from this one.

reviewText:
This is one of the best games I have ever played.
Yes, it is a horror game and yes it is in retro style, but:
Into The Gloom has its own style created by this extraordinary atmosphere and story.

Ohhh yes, the story. The idea of the game is absolutely genius.  The developers managed to convey the story excellent with the help of letters, the environment and these notes on the main menue; and of course the five different endings.
I was really overwhelmed by those endings because it was just brilliant.

Soundtrack: It fits perfect and emphasizes/underlines the games atmosphere.

100/10
I would play it again and again.

reviewText:
Short and sweet game that incorporates pixellated horror in a wonderfully scary atmosphere.

This IS a narrative based horror game, so you'll find yourself navigating streets, and forests, and planes all the while being pursued by things lurking just out of sight within the darkness and the fog. The puzzles are tricky, but nothing that require you to think illogically and use blind luck to solve them. Exploration and quick thinking skills are helpful, since you'll find yourself needing to get out of a terrifying bind, and fast.

Overall, it's a fun horror story game that's worth playing. Remember to play through it again for different endings!

reviewText:
Spooky scary Bag Head Man and glowing red eyes.
On a serious note, I'd like to thank the developers for making this game. I haven''t seen horror quite like this in a long time. The few jumpscares all have build up and actually work quite well, and the atmosphere set up by the low draw distance and the fantastic sound design truly makes me dread going into the next room. The story CAN be a little predictable, but it's told very well and fits nicely into the story in context.
The puzzles in this game are hard. Hard as ♥♥♥♥. This isn't Amnesia where you have to flip six switches until you get the right order, no. This is genuine classic survival horror levels of puzzelry that i haven't seen in a long time. And while each puzzle is incredibbly difficult, they all make sense in the end, giving the game a truly classic horror feel.
There aren't many action scenes, which is fine with me. The only thing you could consider being action is the occasional chase scene with the Stalker. They're loud and scary and had me running around at the speed of sound crying because holy ♥♥♥♥ he sounds like he's right behind me oh ♥♥♥♥ oh ♥♥♥♥. And that's exactly what horror should feel like. Also the small number of these scenes manages to make you not expect them when they eventually do happen.
Overall, Into The Gloom is a pixelized horror game that's both NOT youtuber bait AND genuinely scary. Try a Silent Hill level of atmosphere and puzzling, just minus the combat, while also keeping it's own unique identity.
9/10 bit spooky

reviewText: I really liked the atmosphere of this game it has that sinister, oppressive vibe of the good Silent Hill games like the whole world is colluding against you without being overt. The monochrome and red pallet is a key factor in this. However I really did not like the pixel graphics, I am not one to hold poor graphics against a game but it does feel like it was a conscious decision to make it look a bit pants and it would probably have been improved by a more detailed environment. It has some decent puzzles, mostly solved by exploring and finding the right items. It has multiple endings but the plot is not the greatest and it is relatively short. Overall I am left feeling this game is okay so take it or leave it if it takes your fancy.

reviewText:
This is a hesitant recommendation, because this game has a lot (and I mean A LOT) of rough edges.

On the one hand, the pixelated graphics are actually pretty damn effective and lends themselves to a unique, interesting black and white and red art style. The atmosphere is also genuinely well done, with terrific audio, solid music and creepy details that really stand out. I especially enjoyed a level that takes place in a forest that's sparsely populated by a few different buildings, because that kind of setting just gets me. I love forests because you're surrounded on all sides by trees, making it feel oppressive and bleak.

But then there are the downsides. For one, this game is absolutely loaded with typos, and syntax and grammar errors. Normally I can forgive the occasional typo since, as a writer, I know how hard it is to proof read your own work and catch everything. But there are typos EVERYWHERE in this game, from the text based narration to the scattered notes you find everywhere. It took me out of the game a lot, which is bad for a horror title. The story, what little there is, also feels rather formulaic and that it was written by a teenager (it reminds me a lot of what I used to write in my high school days). In the beginning, there's not much information, then pretty much everything that's going on is explained in a note that is extremely on the nose and feels very out of place (seriously, the note uses the term by the way" to explain what's going on... by the way is something that should be used in a casual conversation
date: not in a horror title whose aim is to unsettle the player).\n\nStill
recommended: if you love horror like I do this title is worth it
hoursPlayed: especially if you can find it on sale. The atmosphere is very
voteText: very well done and manages to be subtle
helpfulPercent: which is something sorely lacking in other titles like Outlast. The environments and sound design are particularly well done. Just don't expect much from the story and get ready for all the typos
votesTotal: in case you haven't figured it out
votesFunny: are abundant and bothered me to no end."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

quite enjoyable for a short, cheap, indie horror game. the pixel graphics are campy, but do not subtract from the atmosphere. the fact that the game does not rely on jump scares, but rather atmosphere and terror when you're being chased makes this game much more enjoyable. the puzzles in the game are simplistic and nothing new, but take a few minutes to understand and offer a moderate challenge. towards the end of the game, the layout of the map changes at certain times, making you think quickly to determine where is safe to run.  the only things i thought that subtracted from the game at all were the lack of jump and crouch, and the inventory screen, but even then, you barely use the inventory, so it's not that big of a deal.
overall, if you've got a couple extra bucks, and you want a couple cheap thrills with a decent execution, i say go for it.

reviewText:
First, let me get my complaints out of the way.

1. The puzzles

While the puzzles in this game are generally well balenced and aren't hard to figure out, there are WAY too many. You will have to solve a puzzle in every single area of the game in order to progress. There isn't anything wrong with something that challenges your mind. But when you're forcing the player to constantly solve puzzles to progress. That really kills the mood and pacing.

2. The save feature

This game only saves your progress upon entering a new area. Anything you do in that area until you progress to a new one won't be saved. So if you decide to quit whilst solving a puzzle, your progress won't be saved and you'll have to do the puzzle all over again. This can be very annoying.

Now, onto what I liked about the game.

1.) The atmosphere

The atmosphere in this game is dark, tense, and dreadful. It gives you that feeling of hopelessness, as if there is no way out of this hellhole except in accepting your fate. Or is it?.....

2.) The sound

The sound design in this game does a really nice job of immersing you into the game's grim story. Everything from the moans and groans the ghosts make to the emotionally stirring soundtrack.

3.) The story

For the sake of not posting spoilers, I'm not going to dive into the details of the story. But if I had to describe it, it would be like this: It feels predictable at first glance, but the longer you play and learn more. You'll start to realize that there are far bigger things at work here than what you orginally expected. Perhaps even bigger than you.

Overall, if you want an excellent horror tale of ghosts and ghouls, try Into The Gloom. It's a very memorable experience that knows how to keep you hooked into its grim, tragic story.

reviewText:
Compared to the pixelated horror games that I've played, Into the gloom is pretty weak and mediocre. Despite being 'trendy' with it's graphics, Into the gloom plays a lot like any generic and boring horror game.

You are walking in a poorly lit corridor. You try a door, it's jammed. You try another one, its lock is broken. This door won't budge. This door is jammed. You look at notes on the wall. Game says it's just stuff, nothing of interest. You try a door, it's jammed. Another note on the wall, just some stuff. Computers won't work. You see random messages in the wall written in blood. You will die." "There is no escape." Another jammed door. Linear corridors. Linear sewers. Message in blood. "He is watching." Jammed doors. A person who hanged himself. You will be seeing a lot of those people.

The actual story of the game is being transmitted to player through random notes. Diary entries. Just stuff
date: nothing of interest. It is clear that this game is intented to be played through more than once. There are keypads
hoursPlayed: puzzles that you cannot solve during your first walkthrough
voteText: but the game won't tell you that. Some of the puzzles feel unfair. A jammed door was actually openable with a key. Who knew.\n\nThe game consists of approximately 6-7 areas. Hospital. Sewer. Prison. Subway. Forest/cemetary. Generic? Just stuff. Nothing of interest. All areas are poorly lit. Random messages written in blood. "You will surely die soon." You will find another notes
helpfulPercent: that someone tore of their diary and left behind in random places. Jammed doors. Doors that won't budge. Doors that have a broken lock. So many excuses why the doors cannot be opened
votesHelpful: and why you must continue this linear passage. Message in blood. Just stuff. Nothing of interest. A hung person. So many people hanging from the ceiling. Did the developer think that the amount of bloody messages and hung people is directly proportional to the amount of horror?\n\nInto the gloom might have been an okay game

intuitive and scarier than this one. And they are free.

reviewText:
Into The Gloom is perhaps the most hilarious game I've ever played in my entire life. Be warned, this review does contain spoilers, so if you're the type who cares for that sort of thing I'd suggest you stop reading.

1. The Graphics

I get it. It's a stylistic design choice. I understand that, I'm not bashing the game for having pixelated graphics. However, when you can't tell where the ♥♥♥♥ you're going because everything is black and white, then you start having problems. BIG problems.  I'd like to think that the developer play-tested this game up and down, so I'd imagine he didn't have much trouble navigating the game. It is a possibility I'm just a blind ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and can't figure out where to go because of it, but hey man it's just way too hard to see ♥♥♥♥. 3/10


2. The Gameplay
Into The Gloom is an atmospheric horror game mostly based around exploration and puzzle-solving, and in both of those departments, it plays quite well. However, you're probably going to want to re-bind the default keys because boy do they suck ABSOLUTE ♥♥♥♥. Z for inventory? Are you ♥♥♥♥ing joking? As far as the puzzle-solving goes, they're challenging. I will admit that I was initially pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at not being able to solve the first puzzle in the game, but after thinking about it I realized I was pretty ♥♥♥♥ing stupid and solved it almost instantaenously. If someone held a gun to my head and told me Name the best thing about Into The Gloom or I'll end your life
date:
I would definitely say Oh ♥♥♥♥ it's the ♥♥♥♥ing puzzle solving!!! Don't shoot!! I have kids!!"

8/10
3. The Story MAJOR SPOILERS
Oh how I loathe the indie scene. Every story-based indie game has to have a stupid ♥♥♥♥ing pretentious story that makes no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sense and tries to challenge your perspective on "how video games should be played!!!" It's complete and utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and
recommended: to quote a favorite Youtuber of mine
hoursPlayed: "reminds me of the pretentiousness of the indie music scene
voteText: right down to the corporatization." Into the Gloom takes place in a kids mind while he's in a coma
helpfulPercent: at least that's what I gathered from the ending I got. And boy does it show up pretty damn quick in this game. So you're just walking around minding your own business
votesHelpful: when out of nowhere Giygas from Earthbound shows up (yes I know it's not him but thats who it ♥♥♥♥ing looks like) and your screen turns black. Then you're treated to an incredibly depressing cutscene where the kids life support is turned off and he's dead
votesTotal: and then the developer poses the question "what do you think happens when u die lol" Then it's over. I understand there are multiple endings

it left a bad taste in my mouth. ♥♥♥♥ it.

1/10 (probably the worst story i've heard all year)


Overall: I'd probably recommend this to the "Gone Home" crowd

reviewText:
Rating: 7/10

Into the Gloom is a pixelated survival horror game with a heavy emphasis on puzzle solving. The game has a very minecrafty" feel to it and while it is not truly scary it certainly can get your heart racing at times.

At the start you wake up in a hospital room and then the hunt is on. It is up to you to explore everywhere you can to find keys
recommended: passcodes and everything one could expect to hunt for in a horror game. There are even documents scattered throughout the game that provide plot details as well as clue you in on how to solve puzzles.\n\nSpeaking of puzzles
hoursPlayed: the puzzles in this game are far better than most big budget horror games that have released over the past few years. A few of the puzzles in the game alter your environment as you work to solve them which makes finding the solution all the more satisfying. The harder puzzles may take you between 5 to 10 minutes to solve. (unless you are completely lost on one which can happen).\n\nThe enemies in this game contrast very well with the slow pace of the puzzles. Let me start by saying there are very few enemies
voteText: but you will learn to fear them fast. This is not a horror type of fear
helpfulPercent: but more of a panic type of fear. You can't combat the enemies; you can only run and after one hit it is game over. Oh yeah
votesHelpful: an the enemies are fast. It may seem like a cheap death
votesTotal: but again this kind of panic contrasts very well with the slow pace puzzle solving.\n\nThere is a story that unfolds throughout the game
votesFunny: however it felt rather lack luster and is overshadowed by the actual gameplay itself. There are extras you can unlock to fill you in on backstory and also multiple endings to unlock so the game does have replay value. You can expect to finish one full playthrough in 3 hours (if you get the good ending).\n\nTo sum it up: The game has a pixelated artstyle. It has heavy focus on puzzle solving and the game has some delightful puzzles to be solved. The horror aspect of the game is more panic than actual horror. The story is overshadowed by the gameplay and is mediocre at best
commentsCount: but it does add replay value with collectibles to unlock for further information. If you are a fan of puzzle solving or survival horror in general
column16: it is hard to pass this game up for the extremely low cost.\n\n"

reviewText: Into The Gloom is an amazing game which includes the Early Access Version and a Brand New Version never seen in Early Access. Anyone who buys this will definately get there moneys worth and more. It is cheap and amazing. Even though it is all pixelated the horrors are still horrific and great graphics for people who like these sort of graphics. It is dark and scary and with puzzles you will find it extremely hard to pass. I hope you guys all buy this and have fun. Don't forget to keep on gaming.

reviewText: The puzzles in this game are challenging, but not impossible. The story is interesting and the addition of multiple endings increases Into the Gloom's replay value. Overall, this was an enjoyable experience that took roughly two hours to complete. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys moderately difficult puzzle games.

reviewText: This game can be frustrating with some of the puzzles. I think i had about 15 jump scares which was amazing. I loved the game. It gave me about 3 hours of gameplay. Now, some people may get hundreds of hours, however, I see at most getting about 10hours. It's not a $60 game though. I really do recommend this game if you like jump scares, I had such a good time with it, and very much worth the buy. Get this game and enjoy a great game. Plus the music is pretty amazing. Has 5 endings, I've unlocked 2 so far.

reviewText:
This game is perhaps the best indie horror game the world has seen in a LONG time. I will list the pros and cons (and inbetween):


PROS:
-Great atmosphere
-Chilling music
-Although the theme of darkness and jumpscares are done to death, this game does it quite well
-(Sort of spoiler) The end part of the game will give you so much anxiety, I haven't felt that tense in a game EVER
-Most people tend to not like the pixel design but it fits so well in this
-great backstory and every character if you read the notes
-This is so much worth  than $3. I would proudly buy this for about $10.
-Replayability
-multiple endings

INBETWEEN:
-This didn't bother me much personally but there are a few spelling and grammar errors
-the puzzles, for some it was easy, for some they're hard. Whenever i was stumped i looked up what to do and felt dumb cause it was a lot more obvious than most would think
-Once you beat the game, and i mean before the first actual ending, scare factor will go down (its an obvious one)

CONS:
-mouse sensitivity is really high, I had it down to 10%. Before you play you NEED to lower it
-This game is pretty muc: Go to point A
date:
to point B) You won't really notice this till you're done playing though
-WHEN YOU SHUT A DOOR IT'S SO LOUD OMG

Overall: 9.5/10

Great horror game. Best there's been in a long time."

reviewText:
A Great Game that deserves a sequel
The atmosphere was perfect. The puzzles were challenging yet had a decent learning curb and the story was actually really interesting, with 5 different endings and some of those endings leaving an opening for a possible sequel.

After completing all endings, I highly recommend this game. A really good example of it's genre, the only complaint is that it leaves you wanting more, as all that it does is done well.

Pros:
*Atmosphere - Makes you feel like you're there, it goes from creepy to calm to soothing and back around again with great timing. This is complimented really well with the music, sound effects and visuals.
*Puzzles - Challenging yet fair (some really challenging), each different with a decent learning curb to them and some 1 or 2 that are quite sneaky.
*Interesting Story - By interacting with the world and examining things, picking up letters, reaching checkpoints and getting to endings, you put the pieces of the story together and experience it as you're right there in the world itself, this is done really well.

Cons
*Too short - All though the game does what it does really well, and the endings are fine, it leaves you wanting more, and some proper closure, a feeling tha the story could go on.
* Quite linear - Though it does feel very open at times, you often find that this door is locked" or "this door is jammed" comes up a lot
date: even though there are 5 different endings and a point in the game that you can make a major decision that effects the story
recommended: it leaves with the idea that there more possiblities that haven't been explored."

reviewText:
Don't let the simple graphics dissuade you from playing this. Into The Gloom is a really cool horror game with intense sound design and music. It doesn't look like much from the screenshots but in motion, the red/white/black art style looks awesome.

It's a bit standard with some exploration, puzzles, notes and monters that chase you from time to time but it's all well made. The chase sequences can be a bit tough though. The game also has multiple endings so there's a bit of replay value and for what they're charging I think it's really worth it. I finished it once in 3.0 hours and I got 3 different endings out of 5 I think.

I was really surprised by this one. Liked it a lot.
